title: Getting Started with Elle
description: Installation, setup, and your first Elle program

content.text: Elle is written in Rust and requires `cargo` to build. Clone the repository and build the interpreter:

git clone https://github.com/yourusername/elle.git
cd elle
cargo build --release
The compiled binary will be at `./target/release/elle`. You can add it to your PATH or use it directly.
Start the interactive REPL (Read-Eval-Print Loop) by running Elle without arguments:
./target/release/elle
You'll see a prompt where you can type Elle expressions:

elle> (+ 1 2 3)
6
elle> (define x 42)
nil
elle> x
42
Create a file `hello.lisp` with your Elle code:

(display "Hello, Elle!")
(newline)
Run it with:
./target/release/elle hello.lisp
You can also make scripts executable with a shebang:

chmod +x hello.lisp
./hello.lisp
Let's write a simple program that greets the user. Create `greet.lisp`:

;; A simple greeting program
(define name "World")
(define greeting (-> "Hello, " (append name) (append "!")))
(display greeting)
(newline)
Run it:
./target/release/elle greet.lisp
Output:
Hello, World!
Elle uses S-expressions (symbolic expressions) with prefix notation. Here are the basics:
**Variables and Definitions**

;; Define a variable
(define x 42)

;; Define a function
(define add (lambda (a b) (+ a b)))

;; Use them
(display (add x 8))
(newline)
**Conditionals**

;; if expression
(if (> 10 5)
  (display "10 is greater than 5")
  (display "10 is not greater than 5"))
(newline)
**Local Bindings**

;; let creates local variables
(let ((x 10)
      (y 20))
  (display (+ x y)))
(newline)
**Sequencing**

;; begin executes multiple expressions in order
(begin
  (display "First")
  (newline)
  (display "Second")
  (newline))
Elle is under active development. Some features described in this documentation may change. Check the [GitHub repository](https://github.com/disruptek/elle) for the latest updates.
Now that you've got Elle running, explore the [Language Guide](language-guide.html) to learn about:
